canonical_explanation.text: Food contains various components called nutrients that our body needs. The major nutrients are carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals. Carbohydrates (found in rice, wheat, sugar, potatoes) and fats (found in oils, butter, ghee, nuts) provide energy. Proteins (found in pulses, milk, eggs, fish, meat) help in body growth and repair. Vitamins (A, B, C, D) and minerals (iron, calcium, iodine) are needed in small amounts to protect us from diseases and keep the body healthy. Water and roughage (dietary fibre) are also essential components of food. A balanced diet contains all nutrients in the right proportions. Deficiency of nutrients leads to diseases: scurvy (lack of Vitamin C), rickets (lack of Vitamin D), beri-beri (lack of Vitamin B1), goitre (lack of iodine), anaemia (lack of iron), and night blindness (lack of Vitamin A).
rules: Carbohydrates and fats are energy-giving nutrients.
Proteins are body-building nutrients needed for growth and repair.
Vitamins and minerals are protective nutrients needed in small quantities.
Roughage (dietary fibre) helps in proper digestion and bowel movement.
Water helps in absorption and transport of nutrients in the body.
A balanced diet contains all nutrients in the right proportions.
Deficiency diseases occur when a specific nutrient is lacking in the diet for a long time.
Iodine test (using iodine solution) turns blue-black in the presence of starch.
Copper sulphate and caustic soda solution turn violet in the presence of protein (biuret test).
Oily patch on paper indicates the presence of fat.

questions.question_text: Which of the following nutrients provides energy to our body?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates are the main energy-giving nutrients. Foods rich in carbohydrates include rice, wheat, sugar, and potatoes. They provide the energy needed for daily activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamins and minerals are protective nutrients needed in small amounts to keep the body healthy. Water is essential but does not provide energy. Carbohydrates are the primary source of energy for the body.

questions.question_text: Proteins are also called:
questions.explanation_correct: Proteins are called body-building nutrients because they help in the growth and repair of body tissues. They are essential for building muscles, skin, hair, and other body parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy-giving nutrients are carbohydrates and fats. Protective nutrients are vitamins and minerals. Roughage is dietary fibre. Proteins specifically help build and repair the body, hence they are called body-building nutrients.

questions.question_text: Which of the following foods is rich in fats?
questions.explanation_correct: Butter is rich in fats. Other foods rich in fats include ghee, cooking oils, nuts, and cheese. Fats provide more energy per gram than carbohydrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice is rich in carbohydrates, spinach is rich in vitamins and minerals, and orange is rich in Vitamin C. Butter is the food item rich in fats among these options.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a protein-rich food?
questions.explanation_correct: Dal (pulses) is rich in proteins. Other protein-rich foods include milk, eggs, fish, meat, soybean, and paneer. Proteins help in the growth and repair of our body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sugar is rich in carbohydrates, potato is rich in carbohydrates (starch), and cooking oil is rich in fats. Dal (pulses) is the protein-rich food among these options.

questions.question_text: Fats provide more energy per gram than carbohydrates.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Fats provide about 9 calories per gram, while carbohydrates provide about 4 calories per gram. So fats give more than double the energy per gram compared to carbohydrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Fats are a more concentrated source of energy than carbohydrates, providing roughly double the energy per gram.

questions.question_text: A child is recovering from an injury and needs food that will help repair damaged body tissues. Which food should be recommended?
questions.explanation_correct: Eggs and dal are rich in proteins, which are needed for growth and repair of body tissues. Since the child is recovering from an injury, protein-rich foods will help repair the damaged tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice, chapati, sugar, and jaggery are rich in carbohydrates (energy). Cooking oil and ghee are rich in fats (energy). For repairing damaged tissues, the child needs protein-rich foods like eggs and dal.

questions.question_text: Which vitamin is also known as the 'sunshine vitamin'?
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamin D is called the 'sunshine vitamin' because our body can produce it when our skin is exposed to sunlight. It is essential for strong bones and teeth as it helps the body absorb calcium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin A is important for eyes, Vitamin B for energy release, and Vitamin C for immunity and healing. Vitamin D is specifically called the 'sunshine vitamin' because sunlight helps our body produce it.

questions.question_text: Which mineral is needed for the formation of haemoglobin in blood?
questions.explanation_correct: Iron is essential for the formation of haemoglobin, the red pigment in blood that carries oxygen. Foods rich in iron include spinach, liver, jaggery, and green leafy vegetables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcium is needed for bones and teeth, iodine is needed for the thyroid gland, and phosphorus is needed for bones. Iron is specifically required for haemoglobin formation in blood.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a good source of Vitamin C?
questions.explanation_correct: Amla (Indian gooseberry) is one of the richest sources of Vitamin C. Other good sources include oranges, lemons, guava, and tomatoes. Vitamin C helps in healing wounds and fighting infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice and bread are rich in carbohydrates, and butter is rich in fats. Amla is the good source of Vitamin C among these options.

questions.question_text: Which mineral is needed for the proper functioning of the thyroid gland?
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine is essential for the proper functioning of the thyroid gland, which controls many body functions. Iodised salt is the most common source of iodine in our diet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is needed for blood, calcium for bones and teeth, and sodium for fluid balance. Iodine is specifically needed for the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones.

questions.question_text: A doctor advises a patient to eat more green leafy vegetables, liver, and jaggery. The patient is most likely deficient in:
questions.explanation_correct: Green leafy vegetables (like spinach), liver, and jaggery are all rich sources of iron. The doctor is recommending these foods because the patient is likely deficient in iron, which can cause anaemia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For calcium deficiency, milk and dairy products would be recommended. For iodine deficiency, iodised salt would be recommended. For Vitamin D deficiency, sunlight exposure would be advised. The recommended foods (leafy vegetables, liver, jaggery) are all iron-rich.

questions.question_text: Calcium is important for our body because it helps in:
questions.explanation_correct: Calcium is essential for making bones and teeth strong. Good sources of calcium include milk, cheese, curd, and green leafy vegetables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Making haemoglobin requires iron. Producing thyroid hormones requires iodine. Preventing scurvy requires Vitamin C. Calcium specifically helps in keeping bones and teeth strong.

questions.question_text: What is a balanced diet?

options.text: A diet that contains only proteins and vitamins
A diet that contains all nutrients in the right proportions
A diet that has equal amounts of all nutrients
A diet that has lots of carbohydrates only

questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet is one that contains all the essential nutrients — carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water, and roughage — in the right proportions as required by the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A balanced diet is not limited to only some nutrients (option A), does not have equal amounts of each nutrient (option C), and is not just carbohydrates (option D). It includes all nutrients in appropriate proportions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a nutrient but is still an essential component of food?
questions.explanation_correct: Roughage (dietary fibre) is not a nutrient because our body cannot digest it, but it is essential because it helps in proper bowel movement and prevents constipation. It is found in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Proteins, fats, and carbohydrates are all nutrients that the body digests and uses. Roughage is the component that is not a nutrient but is still essential for proper digestion and bowel health.

questions.question_text: Why is water considered an important component of our food?

options.text: It helps in absorbing nutrients and removing waste from the body
It is a type of vitamin

questions.explanation_correct: Water is essential because it helps in the absorption of nutrients from food, transportation of nutrients to different body parts, regulation of body temperature, and removal of waste products from the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water does not provide energy like carbohydrates, does not build muscles like proteins, and is not a vitamin. It plays a vital role in nutrient absorption, transport, and waste removal.

questions.question_text: Raju eats only rice and dal every day. His diet is lacking in:
questions.explanation_correct: Rice provides carbohydrates and dal provides proteins, but Raju's diet lacks fats (from oils, butter), vitamins and minerals (from fruits and vegetables), and roughage (from vegetables and fruits). His diet is not balanced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice provides carbohydrates and dal provides proteins, so those are not lacking. However, eating only rice and dal means missing out on fats, vitamins, minerals, and roughage. This is not a balanced diet.

questions.question_text: Scurvy is caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Scurvy is caused by deficiency of Vitamin C. Its symptoms include bleeding gums, weakness, and slow healing of wounds. Citrus fruits like oranges and lemons are rich in Vitamin C.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness, Vitamin B1 deficiency causes beri-beri, and Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets. Scurvy is specifically caused by lack of Vitamin C.

questions.question_text: Rickets is a disease that affects:
questions.explanation_correct: Rickets affects bones, causing them to become soft and weak, leading to bow legs in children. It is caused by deficiency of Vitamin D and calcium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rickets does not affect eyes (night blindness does), skin, or blood (anaemia does). Rickets specifically affects bones, making them soft and bent, especially in children.

questions.question_text: Deficiency of iodine in the diet causes:
questions.explanation_correct: Deficiency of iodine causes goitre, a condition in which the thyroid gland in the neck becomes enlarged (swollen). Using iodised salt in cooking helps prevent goitre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anaemia is caused by iron deficiency, beri-beri by Vitamin B1 deficiency, and scurvy by Vitamin C deficiency. Goitre is specifically caused by iodine deficiency.

questions.question_text: Night blindness is caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Night blindness is caused by deficiency of Vitamin A. People with night blindness have difficulty seeing in dim light or at night. Carrots, papaya, and milk are good sources of Vitamin A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, iron deficiency causes anaemia, and calcium deficiency weakens bones. Night blindness is caused specifically by Vitamin A deficiency.

questions.question_text: A sports player needs lots of energy. Which combination of foods would be BEST for providing energy?
questions.explanation_correct: Chapati (carbohydrate-rich) and banana (carbohydrate-rich) are both excellent energy-giving foods. Since carbohydrates are the main source of energy, this combination would best meet the energy needs of a sports player.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sprouts and paneer are protein-rich (body-building). Spinach and amla are vitamin-rich (protective). Salad and lemon water are low in calories. For energy, carbohydrate-rich foods like chapati and banana are best.

questions.question_text: When we rub a food item on paper and it leaves a translucent (oily) patch, it indicates the food contains:
questions.explanation_correct: When a food item leaves an oily or translucent (greasy) patch on paper, it confirms the presence of fat. This is a simple test to detect fats in food items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starch is tested using iodine solution (turns blue-black). Protein is tested using copper sulphate and caustic soda (turns violet). There is no simple paper test for vitamins. The oily patch on paper specifically indicates fat.

questions.question_text: When a few drops of iodine solution are added to a food item and it turns blue-black, the food contains:
questions.explanation_correct: When iodine solution is added to a food containing starch, it turns blue-black. This is the standard test for detecting starch (a type of carbohydrate) in food. For example, adding iodine to rice or potato would give a blue-black colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protein is tested with copper sulphate and caustic soda (biuret test). Fat is tested by rubbing on paper. The iodine test specifically detects starch (carbohydrate) by turning blue-black.

questions.question_text: A child has weak bones and teeth. Which combination of nutrient and food source would help correct this condition?

options.text: Calcium and Vitamin D — milk and sunlight

questions.explanation_correct: Weak bones and teeth indicate a need for calcium (found in milk, curd, cheese) and Vitamin D (from sunlight), which helps the body absorb calcium. Together they make bones and teeth strong.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron deficiency causes anaemia (not weak bones). Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy. Protein is for growth and repair of tissues. For strong bones and teeth, calcium and Vitamin D are specifically needed.

questions.question_text: Which of the following meals is closest to a balanced diet?

options.text: Rice, dal, vegetable curry, curd, salad, and a fruit
Only fried snacks and cold drinks

questions.explanation_correct: Rice (carbohydrate), dal (protein), vegetable curry (vitamins, minerals, roughage), curd (protein, calcium, fat), salad (roughage, vitamins), and fruit (vitamins, roughage) together provide all nutrients in good proportions, making it closest to a balanced diet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chapati and pickle lack protein, vitamins, and fats. Milk and bread miss roughage and many vitamins. Fried snacks and cold drinks are high in fat and sugar but lack most nutrients. Only option A includes diverse food groups.

questions.question_text: A person has bleeding gums and wounds that heal very slowly. This person is most likely suffering from:
questions.explanation_correct: Bleeding gums and slow wound healing are symptoms of scurvy, caused by deficiency of Vitamin C. Eating citrus fruits, amla, and tomatoes can help prevent and treat scurvy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rickets causes soft/weak bones. Goitre causes swelling of the thyroid gland in the neck. Anaemia causes tiredness and pale skin. Bleeding gums and slow wound healing are specific symptoms of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency).

questions.question_text: Beri-beri is a disease caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Beri-beri is caused by deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine). Symptoms include weakness, swelling in legs, and difficulty in walking. Whole grains, pulses, and nuts are good sources of Vitamin B1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness, Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, and Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets. Beri-beri is specifically caused by Vitamin B1 deficiency.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly pairs the nutrient with its function?
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamins are protective nutrients that help protect the body from diseases. For example, Vitamin C helps fight infections and Vitamin A protects eyesight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbohydrates are energy-giving (not body building). Proteins are body-building (not energy giving). Fats are energy-giving (not protective). Vitamins are correctly paired as protective nutrients.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Vitamin A — (P) Beri-beri
(ii) Vitamin B1 — (Q) Scurvy
(iii) Vitamin C — (R) Rickets
(iv) Vitamin D — (S) Night blindness
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness (S), Vitamin B1 deficiency causes beri-beri (P), Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy (Q), and Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets (R).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matches are: Vitamin A — Night blindness (S), Vitamin B1 — Beri-beri (P), Vitamin C — Scurvy (Q), Vitamin D — Rickets (R). Only option A has all four correct.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Roughage does not provide any nutrient to our body.
Reason: Roughage is not digested by our body but helps in bowel movement.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — roughage does not provide any nutrient. The reason is also correct — roughage cannot be digested by our body, and it helps in proper bowel movement. The reason explains why roughage does not provide nutrients (because it is not digested).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are factually correct. Roughage (dietary fibre) is not digested and thus provides no nutrients, but it is essential for pushing food through the digestive tract and preventing constipation.

questions.question_text: Nutrients that provide energy to our body are called _______ nutrients.
questions.explanation_correct: Carbohydrates and fats are called energy-giving nutrients because they provide the energy needed for all body activities. Carbohydrates are the main source of quick energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Body-building nutrients are proteins. Protective nutrients are vitamins and minerals. The nutrients that provide energy are specifically called energy-giving nutrients.

questions.question_text: Which of the following foods should a person eat to get Vitamin A?
questions.explanation_correct: Carrots and papaya are rich in Vitamin A (they contain beta-carotene which the body converts to Vitamin A). Other sources include milk, eggs, fish liver oil, and leafy vegetables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rice and wheat are mainly carbohydrate sources. Sugar and jaggery provide carbohydrates. Oil and butter are fat sources. Carrots and papaya are the Vitamin A-rich foods among these options.

questions.question_text: Why do doctors recommend eating fruits and vegetables every day?

options.text: They are cheaper than other foods
They are rich in vitamins, minerals, and roughage

questions.explanation_correct: Fruits and vegetables are recommended daily because they are rich in vitamins, minerals, and roughage (dietary fibre). These help protect the body from diseases and maintain proper digestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The recommendation is based on nutritional value, not cost or ease of cooking. Fruits and vegetables are not rich in fat. They are recommended because of their vitamins, minerals, and roughage content.

questions.question_text: A child living in a region with limited sunlight exposure and who does not drink milk may develop:
questions.explanation_correct: Limited sunlight means less Vitamin D production in the body, and not drinking milk means less calcium intake. Both Vitamin D and calcium are needed for strong bones. Their combined deficiency leads to rickets, causing soft and weak bones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scurvy is from Vitamin C deficiency. Night blindness is from Vitamin A deficiency. Goitre is from iodine deficiency. Limited sunlight (Vitamin D) and no milk (calcium) together lead to rickets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about nutrients is INCORRECT?

options.text: Fats store energy for later use
Proteins are mainly needed for providing energy
Vitamins are needed in small quantities

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that proteins are mainly needed for providing energy is incorrect. Proteins are mainly needed for growth and repair of body tissues (body building). While proteins can provide some energy, their primary function is body building, not energy giving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbohydrates do provide quick energy (correct). Fats do store energy (correct). Vitamins are needed in small quantities (correct). But proteins are primarily body-building nutrients, not energy-giving.

questions.question_text: Which of the following vitamins helps in keeping our eyes healthy?
questions.explanation_correct: Vitamin A is essential for keeping our eyes healthy and maintaining good vision, especially in dim light. Rich sources include carrots, papaya, mango, milk, and fish liver oil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin B helps in energy release from food. Vitamin C helps in fighting infections and wound healing. Vitamin D helps in absorption of calcium for bones. Vitamin A is the one specifically important for eye health.

questions.question_text: Malnutrition can occur when a person:

options.text: Eats too much of one type of food and neglects others

questions.explanation_correct: Malnutrition occurs when a person's diet is unbalanced — either lacking in nutrients or having too much of one nutrient and not enough of others. Eating too much of one type of food while neglecting others leads to nutritional imbalance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating a variety of foods, drinking enough water, and eating fruits and vegetables daily are all healthy habits that prevent malnutrition. Malnutrition occurs when the diet is unbalanced.

questions.question_text: A person feels tired easily and looks pale. A blood test shows low haemoglobin levels. This person is suffering from:
questions.explanation_correct: Tiredness, pale appearance, and low haemoglobin are symptoms of anaemia, caused by deficiency of iron. Iron is needed to make haemoglobin in red blood cells. Eating iron-rich foods like spinach, jaggery, and liver can help.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rickets causes bone problems. Goitre causes neck swelling. Beri-beri causes weakness and leg swelling. Fatigue, paleness, and low haemoglobin specifically indicate anaemia (iron deficiency).

questions.question_text: A student performed the following test: she dissolved a food sample in water, added copper sulphate solution and then caustic soda solution. The mixture turned violet. This indicates the food contains:
questions.explanation_correct: The copper sulphate and caustic soda test (biuret test) turns violet in the presence of protein. This is a standard test used to detect proteins in food samples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starch is detected by the iodine test (blue-black colour). Fat is detected by the paper test (oily patch). There is no standard copper sulphate test for sugar. The violet colour with copper sulphate and caustic soda specifically indicates protein.

questions.question_text: In many parts of India, the government promotes the use of iodised salt. This is mainly to prevent:
questions.explanation_correct: The government promotes iodised salt to prevent goitre, which is caused by iodine deficiency. Iodised salt contains added iodine, which fulfils the body's daily iodine requirement for proper thyroid function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anaemia requires iron, night blindness requires Vitamin A, and scurvy requires Vitamin C. Iodised salt specifically provides iodine to prevent goitre.

questions.question_text: A balanced diet is the same for everyone, regardless of age or activity level.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. A balanced diet varies based on age, gender, activity level, and health conditions. A growing child needs more protein, an athlete needs more carbohydrates, and a pregnant woman needs more iron and calcium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A balanced diet is not the same for everyone. Different people have different nutritional needs based on their age, gender, physical activity, and health status.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the deficiency disease and its prevention?

options.text: Scurvy — Eat more rice and chapati
Rickets — Get sunlight exposure and drink milk
Anaemia — Eat more sugar and sweets

questions.explanation_correct: Rickets is caused by deficiency of Vitamin D and calcium. Getting sunlight helps the body produce Vitamin D, and drinking milk provides calcium. Together they prevent rickets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scurvy needs Vitamin C (citrus fruits, not rice). Anaemia needs iron (spinach, jaggery, not sugar). Goitre needs iodine (iodised salt, not just fruits). Only option B correctly matches the disease with its prevention.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is rich in carbohydrates?
questions.explanation_correct: Potato is rich in starch, which is a type of carbohydrate. Other carbohydrate-rich foods include rice, wheat, bread, and sugar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eggs and fish are rich in proteins. Groundnuts are rich in fats and proteins. Potato is the carbohydrate-rich food among these options.

questions.question_text: Which mineral is needed to make our bones and teeth strong?
questions.explanation_correct: Calcium is the mineral essential for making bones and teeth strong. Good sources of calcium include milk, cheese, curd, and green leafy vegetables.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is needed for blood (haemoglobin). Iodine is needed for the thyroid gland. Sodium helps maintain fluid balance. Calcium is the specific mineral for strong bones and teeth.

questions.question_text: A person eats only junk food like chips, burgers, and cold drinks daily. This diet mostly lacks:
questions.explanation_correct: Junk food is usually high in carbohydrates, fats, salt, and sugar but lacks vitamins, minerals, and roughage (dietary fibre). This is why a junk food diet is considered unhealthy and unbalanced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Junk food is typically rich in carbohydrates and fats, so those are not lacking. Cold drinks contain water. Junk food does provide energy (calories). What it lacks is vitamins, minerals, and roughage.

questions.question_text: Sita has swelling in her neck and the doctor says her thyroid gland is enlarged. Which of the following should she include more in her diet?

options.text: More fruits rich in Vitamin C

questions.explanation_correct: Enlarged thyroid gland (goitre) is caused by iodine deficiency. Sita should use iodised salt in her food to get enough iodine for proper thyroid function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vitamin C prevents scurvy, iron prevents anaemia, and calcium strengthens bones. For goitre (enlarged thyroid), iodine is the specific nutrient needed, best obtained from iodised salt.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following tests performed on food item X:
Test 1: Iodine solution added — turned blue-black
Test 2: Rubbed on paper — no oily patch
Test 3: Copper sulphate + caustic soda added — did not turn violet
Food item X most likely contains:
questions.explanation_correct: The iodine test turning blue-black confirms starch is present. No oily patch means no fat. No violet colour with copper sulphate and caustic soda means no protein. So the food contains only starch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Test 1 (blue-black) = starch present. Test 2 (no oily patch) = no fat. Test 3 (no violet) = no protein. Since only the starch test was positive, the food item contains only starch.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST reason for including roughage in our diet?

options.text: It provides energy for physical activities
It helps in the proper movement of food through the digestive tract

questions.explanation_correct: Roughage (dietary fibre) helps in the proper movement of food through the digestive tract, adds bulk to the stool, and prevents constipation. Although our body cannot digest it, it is essential for healthy digestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Roughage does not provide energy (it is not digested), does not build muscles (proteins do that), and is not primarily about taste. Its main role is facilitating smooth movement of food through the digestive system.

questions.question_text: Which pair of deficiency diseases can be prevented by eating green leafy vegetables?
questions.explanation_correct: Green leafy vegetables are rich in iron (preventing anaemia) and Vitamin A (preventing night blindness). Spinach and methi, for example, contain both iron and beta-carotene (which converts to Vitamin A).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rickets needs Vitamin D (sunlight). Goitre needs iodine (iodised salt). Beri-beri needs Vitamin B1 (whole grains). Green leafy vegetables are specifically rich in iron and Vitamin A, preventing anaemia and night blindness.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following children is most at risk of developing a deficiency disease?
(P) Anita eats rice, dal, vegetables, fruits, and milk daily.
(Q) Bharat eats only rice and potato every day.
(R) Charu eats a variety of foods including salad and curd.
(S) Deepa drinks milk and eats eggs and fruits regularly.
questions.explanation_correct: Bharat eats only rice and potato, both of which are rich mainly in carbohydrates. His diet lacks proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals, making him most at risk of developing deficiency diseases like beri-beri, scurvy, or anaemia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anita, Charu, and Deepa all eat a variety of foods providing different nutrients. Bharat's diet of only rice and potato is extremely limited, providing mainly carbohydrates and lacking most other nutrients.
